lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can trace and write vocabulary words (friend, park, play) clearly and accurately.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Write “friend,” “park,” and “play” on the board. Students say the word, trace in air, then copy on paper.
stretchStrategies: “Who Likes What?” Challenge: Write each student’s name on the board. In pairs, students ask each other about animal preferences and report back to the class: “Linh likes cats, but she doesn’t like frogs.” Bonus: students write one sentence about a friend using “and” or “but.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and choose the correct animals.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “It’s big. It has a long nose.” Students guess and point to the animal in the SB.
stretchStrategies: “Who Likes What?” Challenge: Write each student’s name on the board. In pairs, students ask each other about animal preferences and report back to the class: “Linh likes cats, but she doesn’t like frogs.” Bonus: students write one sentence about a friend using “and” or “but.”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together to discuss and mark which animals they and their friends like.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Collaboration) Students interview 2 friends: “Do you like ___?” and mark a ✔ or ✖. Then share results.

items: Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.
Bạn muốn ăn gì? >> you want to eat what? [what do you want to eat?]
This is extremely difficult to master, especially combined with do-support.

Phonics introduces each vowel with one sound, which quickly breaks down past the Kindergarten 2 level. Think of the es in elephant or the as in banana. This does not happen in Vietnamese, where every vowel is pronounced as written.
Bạn có thích ăn bánh mì không? >> you like eat bread? [do you like to eat bánh mì?]
